linkTarget.anchoringText: Visual inspection of these asphaltenes in Fig. 1 suggests somewhat different chemistry. Likewise, the exact identity of phase separated solids depends on the specific conditions of the solution including composition, temperature and pressure.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: A) Typical asphaltenes obtain from solvent precipitation from crude oil. B) asphaltenes precipitated with n-heptane, C) asphaltenes precipitated with n-pentane, D) typical flow assurance asphaltene deposit, E) field tar or bitumen. Since this last material has some mobility, it would generally not be referred to as asphaltene. Nevertheless, naming conventions vary. n-Pentane asphaltenes contain n-heptane asphaltenes along with some heavier ends slightly lighter than the n-heptane asphaltenes which might be referred to as heavy resins.

formatted-caption.caption-text: A) Typical asphaltenes obtain from solvent precipitation from crude oil. B) asphaltenes precipitated with n-heptane, C) asphaltenes precipitated with n-pentane, D) typical flow assurance asphaltene deposit, E) field tar or bitumen. Since this last material has some mobility, it would generally not be referred to as asphaltene. Nevertheless, naming conventions vary. n-Pentane asphaltenes contain n-heptane asphaltenes along with some heavier ends slightly lighter than the n-heptane asphaltenes which might be referred to as heavy resins.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Typical asphaltenes obtain from solvent precipitation from crude oil

linkTarget.anchoringText: High concentrations of asphaltenes correspond to high viscosities; Figure 2 shows the viscosity of asphaltene systems. Fig. 2a shows the huge temperature dependence of viscosity of a solution of asphaltenes in 1-methylnaphthalene, a good solvent for asphaltenes. As expected for anybody who has seen hot versus cold roofing tar, there is an enormous dependence of viscosity on temperature for an asphaltene enriched system.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: a) Viscosity of a solution of n-butane asphaltenes in 1-methylnaphthalene versus temperature, [Sirota et al, 2007] b) viscosity as a function of the concentration of n-hexane asphaltenes, [Lin et al, 1995]. Asphaltenes impart huge viscosity and there is a large temperature dependence of corresponding viscosities.

formatted-caption.caption-text: a) Viscosity of a solution of n-butane asphaltenes in 1-methylnaphthalene versus temperature, [Sirota et al, 2007] b) viscosity as a function of the concentration of n-hexane asphaltenes, [Lin et al, 1995]. Asphaltenes impart huge viscosity and there is a large temperature dependence of corresponding viscosities.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Viscosity of a solution of n-butane asphaltenes in 1-methylnaphthalene versus temperature
viscosity as a function of the concentration of n-hexane asphaltenes

linkTarget.bib:
Sirota and Lin, (2007)
E. B. Sirota , M. Y Lin .; The physical behavior of asphaltenes . Energy Fuels , 21, 2809 2815 , (2007)

Lin et al., (1995)
M S Lin , K M Lumsford , C J Glover , R R Davison , J A Bullin ; The effects of asphaltenes on the chemical and physical characteristics of asphalt . In Asphaltenes: Fundamentals and Applications, ed. EY Sheu, OC Mullins, pp. 155 76 . New York: Plenum, (1995)

linkTarget.anchoringText: In order to evaluate the thermodynamic properties of phase behavior of asphaltenes, it is necessary to have a thermodynamic approach to reservoir crude oils. The cubic equation of state (EoS) is valid and effective for treating gas-liquid equilibria as indicated in Fig. 3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Crude oils consist of dissolved gas, liquids and dissolved solids, the asphaltenes. The cubic EoS is used to treat gas-liquid equilibria, but it is not designed to treat colloidal solids, the asphaltenes. The Flory-Huggins-Zuo (FHZ) EoS treats asphaltene-solution equilibria. [Freed et al, 2010; Zuo et al, 2013] The FHZ EoS utilizes the Yen-Mullins model of asphaltenes to specify the size of relevant asphaltene particles in crude oil. [Mullins et al, 2013]

formatted-caption.caption-text: Crude oils consist of dissolved gas, liquids and dissolved solids, the asphaltenes. The cubic EoS is used to treat gas-liquid equilibria, but it is not designed to treat colloidal solids, the asphaltenes. The Flory-Huggins-Zuo (FHZ) EoS treats asphaltene-solution equilibria. [Freed et al, 2010; Zuo et al, 2013] The FHZ EoS utilizes the Yen-Mullins model of asphaltenes to specify the size of relevant asphaltene particles in crude oil. [Mullins et al, 2013]

linkTarget.bib:
Freed et al., (2010)
D. E. Freed ; O. C. Mullins ; J. Y. Zuo ; Asphaltene gradients in the presence of GOR gradients , Energy & Fuels , 24 (7), 3942 3949 , (2010)

Zuo et al., (2013)
J. Y. Zuo ; O. C. Mullins ; D. E. Freed ; C. Dong ; H. Elshahawi ; D. J. Seifert ; Advances in the Flory-Huggins-Zuo Equation of State for Asphaltene Gradients and Formation Evaluation , Energy & Fuels , 27, 1722 1735 , (2013)

Mullins et al., (2013)
O. C. Mullins ; J. Y. Zuo ; D. Seifert ; M. Zeybek ; Clusters of Asphaltene Nanoaggregates Observed in Oilfield Reservoirs , Energy & Fuels , 27, 1752 1761 , (2013)

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: a) Downhole fluid analysis (DFA) on board a wireline formation tester tool (WFT). DFA can be used to measure a variety of fluid properties. b) An example of an advanced probe to provide clean samples more quickly in a broad array for formations. c) With several DFA stations, thermodynamic evaluation can be performed, here the FHZ EoS for asphaltene gradients.

formatted-caption.caption-text: a) Downhole fluid analysis (DFA) on board a wireline formation tester tool (WFT). DFA can be used to measure a variety of fluid properties. b) An example of an advanced probe to provide clean samples more quickly in a broad array for formations. c) With several DFA stations, thermodynamic evaluation can be performed, here the FHZ EoS for asphaltene gradients.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Downhole fluid analysis (DFA) on board a wireline formation tester tool (WFT). DFA can be used to measure a variety of fluid properties
An example of an advanced probe to provide clean samples more quickly in a broad array for formations

linkTarget.anchoringText: As noted above, a common occurrence is to have a late gas charge into an oil reservoir. Frequently, this gas will rise to the top of the reservoir above the oil. The gas can then diffuse down into the oil column. Figure 5 shows an example of this occurrence.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Gas diffusion part way down a single oil column. A) Cartoon of the diffusive process showing increasing solution gas towards the GOC. A series of these dead oil bottles versus height B) asphaltene gradient, both DFA (black points) and Lab (blue points), showing a large increase of asphaltenes at the base of the column. C) Giant disequilibria gradients of GOR and saturation pressure at the top of the column. Nearly equilibrated GOR and saturation pressure towards the base of the column.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Gas diffusion part way down a single oil column. A) Cartoon of the diffusive process showing increasing solution gas towards the GOC. A series of these dead oil bottles versus height B) asphaltene gradient, both DFA (black points) and Lab (blue points), showing a large increase of asphaltenes at the base of the column. C) Giant disequilibria gradients of GOR and saturation pressure at the top of the column. Nearly equilibrated GOR and saturation pressure towards the base of the column.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Cartoon of the diffusive process showing increasing solution gas towards the GOC
asphaltene gradient, both DFA (black points) and Lab (blue points)
Giant disequilibria gradients of GOR and saturation pressure at the top of the column

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 6 shows a reservoir that has three adjacent fault blocks where gas charged into oil reservoirs. Each fault block shows entirely different reservoir realizations due to reservoir fluid geodynamic (RFG) processes. [Mullins et al, 2016; Pfeiffer et al, 2016; Achourov et al, 2015] These different RFG processes show a variety of mechanisms that yield asphaltene instability.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: A) Reservoir map of three adjacent fault blocks with one well in each. B) The initial condition of gas charge into an oil reservoir is shown. In Well 1, the gas is diffusing down into the oil column and the asphaltenes are also migrating down just as in Fig. 5. At the base of the oil column of Well 1, there is a huge asphaltene concentration of ~35% in the oil. In Well 2, the diffusion process is complete. The solution gas is high and asphaltenes low with equilibration throughout the oil column. The asphaltenes have phase separated into a tar mat at the base as shown by core extracts. In Well 3, above the shale break, the same process occurred of gas and asphaltene migration down until an impermeable layer, shale, was encountered. Below the shale break, lateral gas sweep caused asphaltene deposition throughout the interval.

formatted-caption.caption-text: A) Reservoir map of three adjacent fault blocks with one well in each. B) The initial condition of gas charge into an oil reservoir is shown. In Well 1, the gas is diffusing down into the oil column and the asphaltenes are also migrating down just as in Fig. 5. At the base of the oil column of Well 1, there is a huge asphaltene concentration of ~35% in the oil. In Well 2, the diffusion process is complete. The solution gas is high and asphaltenes low with equilibration throughout the oil column. The asphaltenes have phase separated into a tar mat at the base as shown by core extracts. In Well 3, above the shale break, the same process occurred of gas and asphaltene migration down until an impermeable layer, shale, was encountered. Below the shale break, lateral gas sweep caused asphaltene deposition throughout the interval.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Reservoir map of three adjacent fault blocks with one well in each
The initial condition of gas charge into an oil reservoir is shown

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 7 shows a scanning electron micrograph (SEM) from a core plug in the tar mat. The asphaltene/tar has the characteristic smooth surface along with cracks that can occur with loss of light ends. [Reeder et al, 2016] There is ample asphaltene in the core; this type of tar mat can be a pressure seal or at least a baffle; thus is important when considering aquifer support. Because the gas diffused to the base of the column, the solvent crude oil became unable to hold much asphaltene, thereby becoming worse.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: SEM image of asphaltene/tar deposit in well 2 in the tar mat. The solvent became worse with gas addition; there is a discontinuous increase of asphaltene going from oil to tar.

formatted-caption.caption-text: SEM image of asphaltene/tar deposit in well 2 in the tar mat. The solvent became worse with gas addition; there is a discontinuous increase of asphaltene going from oil to tar.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 8 shows the incipient precipitation that takes place with ‘too much’ asphaltene (solute) added to the crude oil (solvent) at the base of the oil column. Here the concentration is approaching 40% asphaltene in the oil; it is not surprising that the oil cannot dissolve even more asphaltene. The asphaltene is being added by gravity accumulation of nanoparticles towards the base of the oil column.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: SEM micrograph of the initial stages of asphaltene precipitation. Here, high concentrations of asphaltene has been added to the base of the column yielding supersaturation and asphaltene precipitation. With this type of tar/asphaltene deposition, there is a continuous increase of asphaltene content going from oil to tar.

formatted-caption.caption-text: SEM micrograph of the initial stages of asphaltene precipitation. Here, high concentrations of asphaltene has been added to the base of the column yielding supersaturation and asphaltene precipitation. With this type of tar/asphaltene deposition, there is a continuous increase of asphaltene content going from oil to tar.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 9 shows DFA asphaltene and GOR measurements in a field. Most of the field has an equilibrated black oil indicating connectivity. However, Wells A and B show very different fluids at the same subsurface elevation in the oil column. If the conventional density stacking of reservoir fluids applies, then these two wells would appear to be not connected. However, if there is a recent condensate charge in the flank, and a lateral sweep in trap filling, then these two wells could be connected.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: DFA Asphaltene and GOR measurements in several wells in a field. The asphaltenes and GOR are equilibrated in most but not all of the primary sand. The flank of the field has much higher GOR and much lower asphaltene content than expected. Well A contains a condensate-rich fluid while Well B contains a black oil at the same subsurfaceelevation. A proper RFG analysis indicates Wells A and B are connected as proven in production. [Uchytil et al, 2016]

formatted-caption.caption-text: DFA Asphaltene and GOR measurements in several wells in a field. The asphaltenes and GOR are equilibrated in most but not all of the primary sand. The flank of the field has much higher GOR and much lower asphaltene content than expected. Well A contains a condensate-rich fluid while Well B contains a black oil at the same subsurfaceelevation. A proper RFG analysis indicates Wells A and B are connected as proven in production. [Uchytil et al, 2016]

linkTarget.bib:
Uchytil et al., (2016)
S. Uchytil ; V. K. Mishra ; S. S. Betancourt ; J. Guthrie ; J. Huang ; S. Teerman ; A. Nguyen ; S. Stan Evans ; N. Nagarajan ; O. C. Mullins ; Impact of a Secondary Condensate Charge into an Oil Reservoir Evaluated by Downhole Fluid Analysis, Core Analysis, and Production, OTC-27240, Houston , TX, (2016)

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: A simple field map showing condensate charge into the flank in Well A. In addition, the DFA shows an increase of GOR in high permeability sands in Well B consistent with a lateral sweep projecting across the field. Mud gas isotope data can confirm this concept. [Uchytil et al, 2016]

formatted-caption.caption-text: A simple field map showing condensate charge into the flank in Well A. In addition, the DFA shows an increase of GOR in high permeability sands in Well B consistent with a lateral sweep projecting across the field. Mud gas isotope data can confirm this concept. [Uchytil et al, 2016]

linkTarget.bib:
Uchytil et al., (2016)
S. Uchytil ; V. K. Mishra ; S. S. Betancourt ; J. Guthrie ; J. Huang ; S. Teerman ; A. Nguyen ; S. Stan Evans ; N. Nagarajan ; O. C. Mullins ; Impact of a Secondary Condensate Charge into an Oil Reservoir Evaluated by Downhole Fluid Analysis, Core Analysis, and Production, OTC-27240, Houston , TX, (2016)

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Cartoons of the reservoir before and after the start of production. Before production (top), Well A contained a condensate-rich fluid. Two months after production the “condensate bubble” was produced away and the same black oil filling the rest of the field was then produced. In addition, an interference test was performed; Wells A and B are definitely connected. This establishes incontrovertibly that lateral sweep is real and especially likely near charge points. [Uchytil et al, 2016]

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cartoons of the reservoir before and after the start of production. Before production (top), Well A contained a condensate-rich fluid. Two months after production the “condensate bubble” was produced away and the same black oil filling the rest of the field was then produced. In addition, an interference test was performed; Wells A and B are definitely connected. This establishes incontrovertibly that lateral sweep is real and especially likely near charge points. [Uchytil et al, 2016]

linkTarget.bib:

Mullins ; Impact of a Secondary Condensate Charge into an Oil Reservoir Evaluated by Downhole Fluid Analysis, Core Analysis, and Production, OTC-27240, Houston , TX, (2016)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The concepts of lateral sweep plausibly helps explain other reservoirs with upstructure bitumen or tar deposition. Figure 12 shows a reservoir where the wells are drilled near salt upstructure for maximum drainage with aquifer sweep.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Two sister fields both experienced a late gas charge into the oil reservoirs. Data from two upstructure wells are shown. [Dumont et al, 2012] Density-neutron crossover shows the high GOR fluid descending from above as indicated. Tar deposits are indicated on logs and shown in whole core. The asphaltene migrate part of the way down the producing interval and then become stuck in a permeable layer, but resting on shale breaks. It is plausible that these wells near salt also had some degree of lateral sweep causing somewhat local deposition of asphaltenes.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Two sister fields both experienced a late gas charge into the oil reservoirs. Data from two upstructure wells are shown. [Dumont et al, 2012] Density-neutron crossover shows the high GOR fluid descending from above as indicated. Tar deposits are indicated on logs and shown in whole core. The asphaltene migrate part of the way down the producing interval and then become stuck in a permeable layer, but resting on shale breaks. It is plausible that these wells near salt also had some degree of lateral sweep causing somewhat local deposition of asphaltenes.

linkTarget.bib:
Dumont et al., (2012)
H. Dumont , V. Mishra , J. Y. Zuo ; O. C. Mullins ; Permeable tar mat formation within thee context of novel asphaltene science , SPE 163292, KIPCE, Kuwait, (2012)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 13 shows a very typical thin section in a tar zone. There is no direction of “down” that is evident in the images. This is consistent with deposition of asphaltene on solid surfaces, pore walls, throats, or tar, from destabilized nanoparticles of asphaltene in the oil

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Thin section of the tar mat. Black is the tar. The blue is epoxy that displaced movable fluids prior to preparation of the thin section, and white is the sand grain. This image is consistent with significant porosity in the tar zone. [Dumont et al, 2012]

formatted-caption.caption-text: Thin section of the tar mat. Black is the tar. The blue is epoxy that displaced movable fluids prior to preparation of the thin section, and white is the sand grain. This image is consistent with significant porosity in the tar zone. [Dumont et al, 2012]

linkTarget.bib:
Dumont et al., (2012)
H. Dumont , V. Mishra , J. Y. Zuo ; O. C. Mullins ; Permeable tar mat formation within thee context of novel asphaltene science , SPE 163292 , KIPCE, Kuwait, (2012)

linkTarget.anchoringText: At this point, a reservoir is examined where “too much solute”, asphaltene, was added to the base of the reservoir. This scenario likely resulted from incompatible addition of light and heavy oils in the reservoir. The crest is filled with a low GOR black oil, not with a high GOR fluid, so it is less likely that a gas charge gave rise to the incompatibility. The crest is ten or more kilometers away from the rim of this four way sealing anticline as shown in Fig. 14.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: A reservoir within a large anticline has a heavy oil rim underlain by a ten meter tar mat. [Seifert et al, 2012] A huge gradient fits the FHZ EoS with asphaltene clusters from the Yen-Mullins model over the 100 kilometer perimeter with no adjustable parameters. Convective currents are thought to have pumped destabilized asphaltenes to the base of the reservoir adding excess asphaltene thereby forming a tar mat. [Seifert et al 2012, Mullins et al, 2013]

formatted-caption.caption-text: A reservoir within a large anticline has a heavy oil rim underlain by a ten meter tar mat. [Seifert et al, 2012] A huge gradient fits the FHZ EoS with asphaltene clusters from the Yen-Mullins model over the 100 kilometer perimeter with no adjustable parameters. Convective currents are thought to have pumped destabilized asphaltenes to the base of the reservoir adding excess asphaltene thereby forming a tar mat. [Seifert et al 2012, Mullins et al, 2013]

linkTarget.bib:
Seifert et al., (2012)
D. J. Seifert ; M. Zeybek ; C. Dong ; J. Y. Zuo ; O. C. Mullins ; Black oil, heavy oil and tar mats , SPE 161144 ADIPEC Abu Dhabi, UAE, (2012)

Mullins et al., (2013)
O. C. Mullins ; J. Y. Zuo ; D. Seifert ; M. Zeybek ; Clusters of Asphaltene Nanoaggregates Observed in Oilfield Reservoirs , Energy & Fuels , 27, 1752 1761 , (2013)

linkTarget.anchoringText: As seen in Fig. 15, the extracted asphaltene content in the core plugs does not vary monotonically with height. This is a two phase system, trapped heavy oil and occluding asphaltene deposition. The changing ratio of asphaltene content from core plugs depends on the fraction of these two phases. Tight streaks in this carbonate reservoir contain more asphaltene; below tight streaks there is more trapped oil.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Asphaltene content from core plugs from whole core taken in tar mat wells. Each point type (green circles, red circles etc.) correspond to one tar well. There is no reflection of the FHZ EoS in any tar well, the asphaltenes are emphatically not equilibrated even over 2 meters of height in the tar wells. This is because the tar is a two phase system, not just a viscous oil. The asphaltene deposition seals off porosity precluding equilibration. The huge range of asphaltene content in core plugs assures that this is not a single phase material.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Asphaltene content from core plugs from whole core taken in tar mat wells. Each point type (green circles, red circles etc.) correspond to one tar well. There is no reflection of the FHZ EoS in any tar well, the asphaltenes are emphatically not equilibrated even over 2 meters of height in the tar wells. This is because the tar is a two phase system, not just a viscous oil. The asphaltene deposition seals off porosity precluding equilibration. The huge range of asphaltene content in core plugs assures that this is not a single phase material.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Data from two tar wells are plotted in Fig. 16. All components are normalized by the saturates (or paraffins). This normalization is done because otherwise, the other SARA components decrease as the asphaltenes increase from 30% to 60% obscuring the desired effect. As the %-asphaltene increases in the core plug, the plug contains a greater fraction of deposited asphaltene. Fig. 16 shows that only the normalized asphaltene fraction increases with increasing asphaltene deposition, not the resins and not the aromatics.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Analysis of core plugs from two tar wells shown in Fig. 15. [Seifert et al 2012] The SARA components are normalized by saturates to avoid trivial trending of all other components decreasing as asphaltenes increase from 30% to 60%. The tar here is a two phase material. As the asphaltene content increases, the core extracts are more pure with less trapped heavy oil. The normalized asphaltene increases with asphaltene content (of course). However, the normalized resin does not increase. Resin does not preferentially precipitate with the asphaltenes in the deposit. Likewise neither do the aromatics. The deposit is rather high in asphaltene content. [Seifert et al, 2012]

formatted-caption.caption-text: Analysis of core plugs from two tar wells shown in Fig. 15. [Seifert et al 2012] The SARA components are normalized by saturates to avoid trivial trending of all other components decreasing as asphaltenes increase from 30% to 60%. The tar here is a two phase material. As the asphaltene content increases, the core extracts are more pure with less trapped heavy oil. The normalized asphaltene increases with asphaltene content (of course). However, the normalized resin does not increase. Resin does not preferentially precipitate with the asphaltenes in the deposit. Likewise neither do the aromatics. The deposit is rather high in asphaltene content. [Seifert et al, 2012]

linkTarget.bib:
Seifert et al., (2012)
D. J. Seifert ; M. Zeybek ; C. Dong ; J. Y. Zuo ; O. C. Mullins ; Black oil, heavy oil and tar mats , SPE161144ADIPEC Abu Dhabi, UAE, (2012)
